oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Nitty Gritty Dirt Band Interview - Biff Collie - Tape 1
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Nitty Gritty Dirt Band; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie introduction including counting and introducing Jimmie Fadden of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band -- (00:30) Will the Circle Be Unbroken Part 2 is introduced by Collie and Fadden And Fadden Recalls the first Will the Circle Be Unbroken as being an album focused on the group's country roots -- (02:42) Collie and Fadden discuss the recording technique of two-track recording -- (03:09) Fadden recalls "Life's Highway to Heaven" being a track that was recorded in half a day and Fadden and Collie reflect on how two-track recording affected the recording -- (04:48) Collie and Fadden reflect on Johnny Cash being a role model -- (05:13) Collie and Fadden reflect on traditional songs' ability to have variation in title and lyrics -- (05:56) Fadden cerebrates "Grandpa Was a Carpenter" is a great song about people's impact -- (06:41) Collie and Fadden discuss imagery in John Prine songs and reflect on Prine not being recognized as a country artist -- (08:23) "When I get My Rewards" writer Paul Kennerley and lead vocal Levon Helm are celebrated by Fadden as drivers of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's image -- (09:55) Collie and Fadden reflect on Helm's acting career and Fadden discusses how Helm goes above the norm -- (10:38) Collie reasserts Helm is one of his favorite actors and Fadden reflects on how Helm and Fadden's father had similar interests -- (11:50) Fadden and Collie discuss changing "Don't You Hear Jerusalem Moan" from the 'new grass revival' styling -- (12:43) Collie and Fadden reflect on the traditional influence on Will the Circle Be Unbroken Part 2 -- (14:03) Fadden reflects on Helm's work and addresses the value of song writers -- (14:38) "Little Mountain Church House" is told by Fadden to be centered around a 'new traditional' style and calls Ricky Skaggs a terrible singer -- (15:21) Fadden describes what a 'new traditionalist' is -- (15:55) Fadden discusses the techniques needed to fade out on "Little Mountain Church House" using two-track recording -- (16:43) Fadden discusses recording with Jimmy Martin and Skaggs -- (17:36) "And So It Goes" lead vocalist John Denver is reflected on by Fadden telling how the track helped Denver get his career back on track -- (18:53) Collie and Fadden reflect on Denver's attitude directed towards country music -- (21:08) Collie and Fadden address the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's connection to Colorado -- (21:56) Fadden tells how each song only required one recording day -- (22:33) "When It's Gone" is told by Fadden to be a traditional song that took visiting Don Schlitz's help to create -- (23:26) Fadden discusses his favorite songs are those that make emotional statements -- (23:50) Fadden reflects on the amount of artists and self-recorded tracks they allowed on the album -- (24:30) Fadden reflects on "Mary Danced With Soldiers" also being a traditional song sung by Emmylou Harris -- (25:46) Fadden reflects on Harris and changes in playing based on family needs -- (26:49) Collie recalls a phrase referring to success and Fadden reflects on the stress of success -- (27:40) "Riding Alone" is told by Fadden to be originally being named "Range Pickle" and Fadden reflects on the changing perception he had for his band members -- (29:03) Fadden describes the reactions of Chet Atkins and Harris after they recorded "Riding Alone" -- (30:05) Collie and Fadden discuss Fadden recording "I'm Sitting on Top of the World" and working with Martin and Skaggs in the same day -- (31:07) Collie and Fadden reflect on living in Los Angeles, performing at McCabe's, and ditching school -- (33:10) Collie tells of how his daughter visited Long Beach and Fadden addresses his father's service -- (33:39) Collie recalls being at the Andrew Jackson Hotel in Los Angeles being mythical and seeing Carl Butler refuse to cross a lobby -- (34:58) Collie and Fadden discuss the number of tracks based off of traditional music on Will the Circle Be Unbroken Part 2 -- (35:58) Collie recaps Fadden being on the Music City Album Review and Collie and Fadden discuss Liberty Records giving Fadden recording freedom -- (38:07) Collie and Fadden discuss Scruggs' helpfulness in collaborating artists for the album -- (39:10) Fadden brings up the change in drumming for the new album; this was due to an abundance of guitar payers -- (39:55) The year "Lovin' on the Side" was written is joked about by Fadden, Fadden reflects on the 'two-step' style of the song, and Paulette Carlson is told to be a major factor -- (41:31) Collie and Fadden reflect on Carlson coming from Minnesota and the re-writes done on "Lovin' on the Side" -- (42:17) "Lost River" by Michael Martin Murphey is reflected on by Murphey as a song about Canada -- (42:46) Fadden recalls playing Harmonica with a symphony in downtown Nashville (43:00) Fadden tells that the album is an homage to the band's friend group and the changes of time -- (44:16) Fadden tells of how "Bayou Jubilee" pianist Bruce Hornsby was asked to perform on "Bayou Jubilee" -- (45:42) Fadden describes "Blues Berry Hill" violin player Vassar Clements performance style and recalls Clements describing his playing technique -- (47:01) Fadden describes how "Blue Berry Hill" got its name and Fadden and Collie discuss the various terms used to describe various aspects of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band -- (48:15) "Turn of the Century" is described to be a J. Fred Knobloch and Dan Tyler song that is the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's outlook on the future -- (49:02) Collie and Fadden joke about non-ideal situations -- (49:28) "One Step Over the Line" is addressed as a Rosanne Cash and John Hiatt track Fadden believes to be a 'Honkey Tonk" song -- (50:28) Fadden and Collie joke about bird calls while discussing "You Ain't Goin' Nowhere" and its relationship with the Country Rock album -- (51:21) Fadden reflects on Chris Hillman's musical career -- (52:21) "The Valley Road" is described as Fadden as the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's fastest track and recalls another record company employee listening in to the recording -- (53:25) Fadden describes Hornsby's styling and similarity to Helm -- (54:28) "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" is the only multi-track recording and Fadden and Collie reflect on the staggering number of artists -- (55:36) Fadden details Roy Acuff's performance in the recording -- (56:34) Collie has Fadden recall the time he had met Acuff at Acuff Rose and Fadden reflects on talent being guided by the audience -- (58:25) Fadden discusses the change in music air-time with the change in radio -- (58:59) Collie and Fadden discuss the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's different styling and Collie addresses the value of Will the Circle Be Unbroken -- (59:53) Fadden asserts the historical significance of the Will the Circle Be Unbroken without the intention to be historically significant -- (1:02:08) Collie steers the conversation to Acuff and Fadden describes playing ping pong with Acuff to determine what kind of people made the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band -- (1:03:10) Fadden describes the first encounter with Acuff in the studio and Fadden and Collie describe the pressure of the situation Fadden faced -- (1:04:16) Fadden shows his appreciation for Scruggs' contributions on the album; this includes the album's final track "Amazing Grace" -- (1:05:17) Collie recaps the interview for Fadden and Fadden corrects Collie about John Denver -- (1:06:28) Fadden addresses Murphey and McGuinn -- (1:06:36) Collie addresses Roseanne Cash and Hiatt [incomplete]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Nitty Gritty Dirt Band; Collie, Biff;
